text:
'we miss him so much' Tributes for learner driver who commited suicide after failing driving test for the SIXTH time 
Sam Crook, 23, lied to pals that he had passed and sometimes drove illegally to hide the truth By ROBIN PERRIE Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments A LEARNER driver desperate to pass his test killed himself after failing it for the sixth time, a court heard. 
Sam Crook, 23, told people he had passed and sometimes drove illegally so he didn’t have to admit to pals that he didn’t have a licence. 3 Sam took his own life after failing his sixth test 
When he failed it again for the sixth time he couldn’t cope and killed himself by inhaling carbon monoxide at his home, his inquest was told. 
Coroner David Roberts said: “It seems clear passing his test was something that was very, very important to him. 
“Failure to pass that test was a devastating blow. I think he pinned a lot of hope on it. Passing it would mean his lie was long gone and behind him and he could get on with his life.” 3 Sam was working as a mental health support worker 
Sam, of Carlisle, had an English degree from Northumbria University and was a support worker for people with mental health problems. 
But he suffered from anxiety and depression himself and had received treatment.

Tia, who found his body, added: “Every day is different. You have good days and bad days. You can’t really put it into one word. Sometimes you take one step forward and two steps back.” 
His mother Mary, 48, said: “Sometimes you have to take an hour at a time. 
It was just getting through that hour and the next hour.” Mary struggled to cope after Sam’s death in August 2015 and her cousin suggested she take up running. 
She joined a local club and started doing the popular weekly park runs. 3 Sam had received treatment for depression and anxiety 
She said: “I think if I hadn’t started running I’d have been in a terrible state. I think the running has really helped. 
“It helped with the psychological pain that I felt because the running was physically hurting me. It was kind of transforming it. It gave me a release. 
“It’s really hard to cope with day to day stuff. 
“We just miss him so much. Christmases are difficult, birthdays are difficult. You think of a joke and you think Sam would think that’s hilarious and then you realise you can’t tell him.” For confidential emotional support call the Samaritans helpline 24 hours a day, 365 days a year by dialling 116 123.
